articles.title: Carlos Prates Called out Jack Della Magdalena
articles.description: Carlos Prates just called out Jack Della Maddalena ‚Äî and Chael Sonnen wants to know the same thing you do: why? Is it fair game to call out a guy coming off a loss when that loss was for a world title? Chael says yes, absolutely‚Ä¶ and then explains why fighters get this wrong all the time. Chael breaks down why card placement matters more than rankings, why calling up is always better than calling down, and why Prates targeting Jack actually makes complete career sense. He also ties in Brendan Allen calling out Dricus Du Plessis and how the middleweight and welterweight divisions are both wide open if you understand how the game really works. From Islam Makhachev‚Äôs options to Shavkat‚Äôs return, Ian Garry‚Äôs position, the rumors around Belal Muhammad, and whether Dana White promised Movsar a title shot ‚Äî Chael walks through the whole 170 landscape and shows where Prates fits into it. But the real question is the one Chael wants Prates himself to answer: Why Jack? Is it the name? The position? A strategic play? Something personal? There‚Äôs no wrong answer ‚Äî but Chael wants to hear it. #MMA #ChaelSonnen #UFCTalk #JackDella #CarlosPrates #UFC #Welterweight #FightBreakdownBad Guy Inc merch now available at https://BadGuyInc.com Click here to subscribe: https://bit.ly/3FrHIPK Follow me on IG: https://bit.ly/3HY7BIE Follow me on Twitter: https://bit.ly/3tvY5J7 Follow me on Threads https://www.threads.com/@sonnench

articles.title: Can Jake Paul Last 4 Rounds?
articles.description: Jake Paul looks good, guys. New training footage just dropped of Jake on the heavy bag, and Chael breaks down why it actually matters more than people want to admit. Everyone loves to say, ‚ÄúMitts and bag work don‚Äôt count,‚Äù but if you can compare old tape to new tape, you can see real changes in timing, speed, footwork, conditioning, and power. That‚Äôs all quantifiable. In this video, Chael explains why Jake Paul has multiple ways to ‚Äúwin‚Äù against Anthony Joshua that go beyond just getting his hand raised. Showing up, surviving rounds, slipping combinations, and simply being able to touch a world-class heavyweight boxer are all real milestones. Chael also lays out the uncomfortable truth: Jake‚Äôs power is not going to scare a 240-pound Olympic champion ‚Äî so the game plan shouldn‚Äôt be ‚Äúknock him out,‚Äù it should be ‚Äútouch and move.‚Äù Using examples from George Foreman, Uriah Hall, Francis Ngannou, and Conor McGregor vs. Floyd Mayweather, Chael argues that Jake‚Äôs best chance is a high-volume, tagging approach, not loading up and planting. Based on this latest heavy bag session, Jake is checking the right boxes. More analysis on Joshua vs Paul is coming, but for now: Jake has never looked better. #JakePaul #AnthonyJoshua #Boxing #ChaelSonnen #FightBreakdown #TrainingFootage Guy Inc merch now available at https://BadGuyInc.com Click here to subscribe: https://bit.ly/3FrHIPK Follow me on IG: https://bit.ly/3HY7BIE Follow me on Twitter: https://bit.ly/3tvY5J7 Follow me on Threads https://www.threads.com/@sonnench

articles.title: Why Doesn‚Äôt Khamzat Know His Next Fight?
articles.description: Khamzat Chimaev says he‚Äôs open to anyone ‚Äî Sean Strickland, Nassourdine Imavov, Paulo Costa, even moving up to 205 to fight Alex Pereira ‚Äî yet somehow he still has no opponent. That‚Äôs the part Chael Sonnen can‚Äôt figure out, and it‚Äôs the central question of this breakdown: How does a star like Chimaev not know who he‚Äôs fighting next? Chael walks through the entire middleweight landscape: canceled matchups, replacements, and the domino effect that‚Äôs taken names like Fluffy Hernandez, Brendan Allen, and Roman Dolidze off the board. With Strickland booked, Fluffy now fighting Strickland, and Brendan Allen fresh off a win, the process of elimination points directly to Imavov. Yet Chimaev insists he doesn‚Äôt know and even downplays the idea by saying they've trained together and share cultural ties ‚Äî something that cools the matchup rather than heats it up. Chael breaks down why that stance creates promotional obstacles, why fighters normally have a much clearer picture behind the scenes, and why it‚Äôs surprising that months after the Dricus du Plessis fight, Chimaev is still floating in uncertainty. If he truly wants Pereira at 205, that‚Äôs another layer entirely ‚Äî Pereira‚Äôs situation at light heavyweight is just as quiet. This is one of the rare times Chael sees a top contender completely in the dark about his next assignment, and that alone is a story. articles.title: Rogan: ‚ÄúTravesty‚Äù If Jon Jones Isn‚Äôt on White House Card
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChaelBad If the UFC White House card features Tom Aspinall vs Ciryl Gane for the heavyweight title and Jon Jones vs Alex Pereira in a non-title superfight on the same night‚Ä¶ who actually main events? That‚Äôs the question Chael Sonnen takes a scalpel to in this video. Chael revisits Joe Rogan calling it a ‚Äútravesty‚Äù if Jon Jones isn‚Äôt on the White House card, then presses the follow-up nobody seems to ask: what kind of travesty are we talking about? Is it worse to not have the greatest fighter of all time on the show, or to close the biggest event ever without a world title in the final slot? He examines the new era of matchmaking where an interim title fight like Gaethje vs Pimblett can headline over an undisputed women‚Äôs championship, and applies that same logic to Jones‚ÄìPereira versus Aspinall‚ÄìGane. On top of that, Chael points out the uncomfortable detail everyone ignores: Jon Jones isn‚Äôt even ranked in the top 15 right now. How does a non-title bout between an unranked fighter and a champion at another weight fit above every belt on the card? This isn‚Äôt just about names on a poster ‚Äî it‚Äôs about star power, card hierarchy, and what the UFC wants the world to see last on the biggest stage it‚Äôs ever had. articles.title: Does anyone else think Merab won the first 3 rounds?
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChaelBadBad Aljamain Sterling publicly scored the first three rounds for Merab, and he‚Äôs not alone ‚Äî Chael heard that same sentiment repeated all night by fighters and coaches watching alongside him. But what complicates the scoring even more is Daniel Cormier‚Äôs cageside observation: Merab yelled out in pain multiple times after body shots from Yan. Under MMA rules, a verbal cry of pain can count as a submission, and it doesn‚Äôt require a hold, a choke, or even physical contact at the moment it‚Äôs uttered. So why wasn‚Äôt the fight stopped? Chael also revisits historical precedents, including Matt Hughes calling ‚Äútimeout‚Äù mid-fight and athletes in PFL losing contests due to injury stoppages they didn‚Äôt intend. With fence grabs, unanswered questions in the officiating, and a debate about whether the fight should lead into a trilogy, this matchup raises serious issues about consistency in MMA rules and enforcement. Whether you scored it for Yan, for Merab, or saw it as a razor-thin technical fight, one thing is clear: multiple key moments in this bout deserve a closer look. articles.title: Chimaev Keeps Targeting Alex Pereira‚Ä¶
articles.description: Khamzat Chimaev keeps calling out Alex Pereira ‚Äî again, and again, and again. And Chael Sonnen believes this isn‚Äôt just random matchmaking anymore. This feels personal. The challenge now is figuring out why. Chael breaks down the timeline of Chimaev‚Äôs callouts, starting back when Khamzat was still flirting with 170 and talking about becoming a champ-champ. Back then, calling out Pereira made competitive sense. But now that Chimaev has abandoned welterweight and even hinted at leaving middleweight, the continued fixation on Alex Pereira raises real questions. What‚Äôs driving it? Respect? Ambition? Something behind the scenes? A snub? Training history? A cultural wrinkle? Chael explores every possibility. Meanwhile, Pereira isn‚Äôt ignoring him. Poatan has responded multiple times ‚Äî telling Khamzat he‚Äôs focused on Jon Jones but inviting him to 205 ‚Äúif you can get here.‚Äù He even accepted the idea of a grappling match. That back-and-forth alone shows this matchup isn‚Äôt as far-fetched as people think. Chael then explains why Carlos Ulberg, despite owning the rankings argument, isn‚Äôt generating the momentum needed to secure a Pereira fight ‚Äî and why that opens a lane for Chimaev if he stays loud and strategic. If Pereira‚ÄìJones doesn‚Äôt materialize, Pereira returning to 205 in need of a big fight suddenly makes Khamzat a very real option. This is how unexpected superfights get born ‚Äî slowly, then all at once. articles.title: Is Jake Paul vs Anthony Josuha Off? Chael Responds
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChaelBadBad Rumors that Jake Paul vs. Anthony Joshua is ‚Äúoff,‚Äù are getting downright bizarre. Former heavyweight champion Bermane Stiverne claims he ‚Äúheard somewhere‚Äù that Jake is injured, the fight is canceled, and a black eye from sparring shut the whole thing down. Chael breaks down why none of that adds up ‚Äî starting with the simple fact that Jake Paul has no one to pull out from. He‚Äôs the one promoting the event. In this video, Chael dismantles the rumor piece by piece, from Stiverne‚Äôs shaky claims to the idea that a professional fighter would cancel a mega-fight over a black eye. He also draws a powerful comparison to Joshua Van, who walked into a fight nobody believed he could win ‚Äî and did it anyway. That‚Äôs what separates real competitors from spectators who speculate. If you‚Äôre following the buildup to Joshua vs. Paul, or if you just want clarity on what‚Äôs real and what‚Äôs nonsense, this is the breakdown to watch. articles.title: Islam vs Usman: This Is the Fight
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChael 170 pounds is murderers‚Äô row, and that‚Äôs exactly why Islam Makhachev needs Kamaru Usman. Not just for a payday, not just for a name ‚Äì for legacy. Chael breaks down the current state of the UFC welterweight division, from killers like Michael Morales, Sean Brady, Ian Garry, Belal Muhammad, and Shavkat Rakhmonov, to what really makes sense next for Islam. On paper, you can argue a lot of contenders‚Ä¶ but when you factor in history, greatness, and what actually moves the needle, one name keeps coming back: Kamaru Usman. Chael explains why giving Usman a title shot isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúrewarding‚Äù him for a dominant career ‚Äì it might actually be the best thing you can do for Islam. If Makhachev goes out and does to Usman what even Khamzat Chimaev couldn‚Äôt, that changes the GOAT and pound-for-pound conversations overnight. We also get into Georges St-Pierre, Khabib Nurmagomedov, and how Islam‚Äôs resume will age as guys like Arman Tsarukyan rise to the top. This is a cold sport, and matchmaking at this level is about more than rankings. It‚Äôs about legacy, star power, and who you beat when it matters. articles.title: Trump Claims White House Card's Only Title Fights
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL! #bruntpoChaelBad President Donald Trump just dropped a bombshell about the rumored UFC White House card ‚Äì and whether he nailed every detail or not, the theme of what he said is wild. He floated June 14th, talked about nine title fights, and even used the phrase ‚Äúonly title fights.‚Äù Now, maybe one of those details is off‚Ä¶ but if even one of them is right, everything changes. Chael breaks down what an all-title-fight card (or even an all-title-fight main card) would really mean. If it‚Äôs ‚Äúonly title fights,‚Äù where does that leave all the rumors we‚Äôve heard about Conor McGregor, Jon Jones vs. Alex Pereira, and the heavyweight picture around Tom Aspinall and Ciryl Gane? Chael walks through how you could still make Conor a title fight with Max Holloway‚Äôs BMF belt, how Jones‚ÄìPereira could slide into a championship scenario, and what happens if Aspinall stays on the shelf long enough to force an interim or undisputed shake-up. This isn‚Äôt just fantasy matchmaking; it‚Äôs trying to read between the lines of what the host of the event is saying. If Trump is talking nine title fights and ‚Äúonly title fights,‚Äù even if the numbers are fuzzy, the direction is clear: the UFC is aiming for something historically stacked. Where does this all land? We‚Äôll see. But it sure sounds like we‚Äôre in for a night loaded with gold. articles.title: Should Ilia Topuria Lose His Belt?
articles.description: Get 15% OFF The House of Atlas Razor Kit + Before and After Set with the code CHAEL at https://www.houseofatlas.com/CHAEL! #houseofatlaspod Should Ilia Topuria still be the champion? That‚Äôs the question circling the UFC offices right now, and it‚Äôs a lot colder ‚Äî and a lot more complicated ‚Äî than fans realize. I just walked out of the UFC Performance Institute in Las Vegas, and everybody has an opinion on Ilia Topuria. Some say he‚Äôs the best boxer in MMA, others say he‚Äôs the future face of the sport, maybe even headlining the White House card. But for the first time, a very respected voice hit me with a different argument entirely: Ilia should have been stripped. Not sidelined. Not given grace. Stripped. This person walked me through the history of the interim title ‚Äî why it exists, when it‚Äôs used, and why illness or injury has always been the deciding factor. They brought up Dominick Cruz‚Äôs three-and-a-half-year layoff, ACL after ACL, and the compassion that kept him champion. Their claim? Ilia‚Äôs situation doesn‚Äôt fall under illness or injury‚Ä¶ so why keep the belt? Now, I don‚Äôt agree. I believe Ilia Topuria has handled a tough situation with transparency and courage. He even told the UFC to move on without him if needed ‚Äî a man‚Äôs move. But the question remains: Should a champion keep his title if he refuses to fight and it‚Äôs not due to injury? This is the cold side of a cold sport. And it‚Äôs worth discussing. articles.title: The ONLY solution to stopping eye pokes in the UFC... #ufc
articles.description: Bare-knuckle wrestling is intense, but Chael Sonnen argues that blaming the gloves is a massive copout. In this clip, he explains why fighters must be held accountable for actions like eye pokes, grabbing the fence, or kicking opponents while down ‚Äî regardless of whether gloves are involved. Chael points out that referees and fans often label these incidents ‚Äúunintentional,‚Äù but that mindset ignores responsibility. Even without gloves, fighters can and should avoid fouls. The real issue isn‚Äôt the equipment ‚Äî it‚Äôs accountability. If someone pokes an opponent in the eye, someone is at fault, plain and simple. This clip is essential for anyone following MMA rules, bare-knuckle combat, or fighter safety. Chael‚Äôs analysis highlights how leniency for ‚Äúaccidents‚Äù undermines fairness, sets poor precedents, and affects how fights are judged. He stresses that proper enforcement and accountability maintain the integrity of the sport, rather than blaming gloves or equipment. For fans of MMA, bare-knuckle fighting, fighter safety, and insider fight analysis, this breakdown delivers Chael Sonnen‚Äôs sharp and unfiltered perspective.
